prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Tale of Reglet and Furniture

In wond'rous lands of Reglet bright,
Where Furnitree grows tall,
And chair-legs twisted in delight,
While cupboard giants brawl.

"Beware the Reglet's crafty claws!
The teeth of chest and drawer!
Beware the mirrored flush - no pause!
And shun the Ironjaw!"

He took his trusty spanner-sword
In hand with dauntless mien:
Long time the manxome foe he sought—
Then rested by a screen.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Reglet, with eyes of flame,
Came sniffling through the underwood,
And gurgled as it came!

One, two! One, two! His blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"Has thou slain the Reglet? Come to me!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his glee.

'Twas brilliant, and the sunlit beams
Did gyrate in joyous dance;
All furnitree did cease their screams,
The chairs began to prance.

And so, our hero boldly strode
Through realms of wood and woe,
With spanner-sword at his side,
His face aglow with gleams.
label: medium
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title present: “The Tale of Reglet and Furniture” line before first stanza, non-empty; yes.</C1_think>
<C2_think>Stanzas: counting stanza breaks, poem has 8 stanzas. Count lines per stanza: first stanza 4 lines, second 4, third 4, fourth 4, fifth 3, sixth 3, seventh 4, eighth 4. Two stanzas have <4 lines (5th and 6th have 3 lines). So not all stanzas have 4 lines. Total stanza count 8 is good. But all stanzas must be quatrains: no.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Ballad meter echo: check ≥60% of stanzas show longer/shorter line alternation with ≥2 content words difference line to line. The original poem typically alternates 8–9 syll. lines with 5–6 syll. lines. Here many lines vary but not consistently. Also skipping stanzas with 3 lines. Among quatrains: mostly alternating length is unclear or weak, borderline. Less than 60% clearly follow alternating long-short lines. So no.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Ballad rhyme (lines 2 and 4 rhyme at least 60% of stanzas, with no AABB dominance): rhyme pairs in stanzas mostly: stanza1 (lines2-4: “tall” / “brawl”) rhyme; stanza2 (pause/ironjaw) half rhyme; stanza3 (mien/screen) rhyme; stanza4 (flame/came) rhyme; stanza5 only 3 lines, lines2 and 4 missing; stanza6 only 3 lines (no 4th line); stanza7 (me/Callooh/Callay) 2-4 lines missing or different; stanza8 (side/gleams) no rhyme in 2,4 positions; rhyme coverage ≈4-5 stanzas rhyme (out of 8); over 60%. Slant rhyme present. No evidence of AABB dominance (only one clear AABB is stanza8? No, no AABB). So yes.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Ring composition: final stanza contains content words echoing the opening stanza (original “brillig,” “slithy toves,” “gyre and gimble in the wabe”). In model, final stanza references "hero," "wood and woe," "spanner-sword," "gleams" — no clear repeated content words or phrases from first stanza (“Reglet,” “Furnitree,” “chair-legs,” “cupboard giants”). Final stanza does not echo the opening stanza clearly with repeated words or a refrain. No ring echo: no.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Warning/admonition present early: second stanza includes “Beware the Reglet's crafty claws! … Beware … shun the Ironjaw!” clearly admonition. Yes.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation/armament before encounter: protagonist takes "his trusty spanner-sword in hand," rests by a screen before the encounter. Matches the preparation phase. Yes.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Encounter with adversary: fourth stanza describes the Reglet with eyes of flame coming through underwood, matching clear confrontation. Yes.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Slaying/decisive action: fifth stanza describes blade going snicker-snack, leaving Reglet dead with its head, clear decisive act. Yes.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return/celebration: sixth and seventh stanzas include celebration and chortling joy, and hero’s return with spanner-sword; but stanza 6 only 3 lines (incomplete stanza), stanza 7 is a short celebration. Partial but present. Yes.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Coinage count ≥8: Coinages include Reglet, Furnitree, chair-legs (compound?), cupboard giants, Ironjaw, spanner-sword, sniffling, gurgled (arguably standard English), uffish repeated, snicker-snack (canonical), galumphing (canonical), brilliant (standard word), gyrate (standard word), prance (standard word). Count distinct invented coinages: Reglet, Furnitree, Ironjaw, spanner-sword, chair-legs (compound?), cupboard giants (compound? plural?), underwood (controversial, more a real word), sniffling (standard English), gurgled (standard English). So weak in coinages, maybe 4-5 distinct coined words at best. Below 8. No.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Coinage spread: Each stanza should contain at least 1 coinage. Checking each stanza: 1st with Reglet, Furnitree, chair-legs, cupboard giants (coinages present). 2nd with Reglet, Ironjaw (coinages). 3rd “spanner-sword” coinage present. 4th “Reglet” repeated, “underwood” may or may not be coined, “sniffling” and “gurgled” standard English though sound mimetic; ambiguous but probably no coinage per stanza in some of last stanzas. Stanza 5: “blade” and “snicker-snack” canonical, no new coinage. Stanza 6: chortled (standard), “beamish” missing (only canonical in original, but not here). No coinage. Stanza 7 and 8: no coinages or only standard words. So not all stanzas have coinage. No.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Creature named and central to action (non-canonical and not Jabberwock): Reglet is named and central; yes.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeia ≥2 bursts: “snicker-snack!” is canonical; “sniffling” and “gurgled” are mimetic but less onomatopoeic bursts. Only one clear onomatopoeic burst “snicker-snack!” present, no other burst or exclamation like “Pop!”, “Hiss!”. No.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Alliteration/consonance in minimum 2 stanzas: “Furnitree grows tall,” “chair-legs twisted in delight,” some internal consonant repetition but weak. “Beware the Reglet’s crafty claws!” - clear alliteration “crafty claws.” “Spanner-sword” compound repeats s+ sounds. At least two stanzas with clear alliteration – yes.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Arc order: Early warning/admonition (stanza2), preparation (stanza3), encounter (stanza4), slaying (stanza5), return/celebration (stanza6-7). The order is canonical. Yes.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No verbatim canonical lines: No exact canonical lines from Lewis Carroll are used; words are changed. “snicker-snack” and “galumphing” are canonical words but standard vocabulary usage only. No verbatim line matches. Yes.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical budget ≤8 tokens: Canonical tokens used: “manxome” (stanza3), “uffish” (stanza4), “snicker-snack” (stanza5), “galumphing” (stanza5), and “beamish” (stanza6) — but “beamish” appears as “bright” is used instead. “Manxome” and “uffish” appear. So 3-4 canonical tokens used. Under threshold. Yes.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable tightness: longer lines ~8-9 syllables, shorter lines ~5-7 syllables per stanza. Check stanza1: 1st line 7 syll. (“In wondrous lands of Reglet bright”) slightly short; 2nd line “Where Furnitree grows tall,” 5 syll; 3rd line 7; 4th line 5. The pattern is inconsistent/stretched. Some stanzas have lines over 9 syllables or under 5 in longer/shorter positions, so syllable structure is loose and not tight. No.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme variety (2,4 rhymes varied, no more than 2 repeats): rhyme repeats include “brawl” rhymes (stanza1 end), “draw/flush” (weak), “mien/screen” new rhyme, “flame/came” new rhyme, “snicker-snack” unique. Some reuse of rhyme endings but no exact repetition beyond twice. Probably yes.</C20_think>
<C21_think>Lexical repetition guard (no word overused >5x or >8% content words): “Reglet” is repeated but less than 5 times, no high overuse. No problematic lexical repetition. Yes.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinage variety ≥4 roots, not dominated by suffixes: Only about 4-5 coinages total, with distinct roots (Reglet, Furnitree, Ironjaw, spanner-sword, chair-legs compound). No dominant suffix group. Yes.</C22_think>
<C23_think>Topic adherence: Poem addresses a Reglet fight/adventure, clearly on topic with Jabberwocky narrative adapted. Yes.</C23_think>
<C24_think>Subtext: Subtle subtext in heroic adventure and domestic/furniture metaphor; somewhat coherent motif of struggle against household menace, echoes original undertone. Yes.</C24_think>
</think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blued screw in a movement". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Title: The Blued Screw's Labyrinthine Quest

In twigled dank, where whistles tweet,
A blued screw lay, in slumber sweet.
Upon the loam of the daisy's breath,
Awash in dreams of movement deft.

"Arise," said the voice of the greeps in glee,
"Come find your place in the mechanee."
With rasps and grunts, awoken from rest,
The blued screw embarked on its quest.

Through timberland forests, past emerald lakes,
A Querulous Quagmire, where fear partakes.
In metallic mirth, the screw did whirl,
Beneath the sun's own spinning pearl.

To the heart of the clockwork beating core,
Our blued screw ventured, seeking rapport.
The gears did grind, the cogs did sing,
In intricate dances, metal limbs swing.

A legion of brothers, metallic and bold,
The blued screw curtsied, and did extol.
Surrounded by brethren, in colors they bloomed,
United, entwined, harmonious thrummed.

From worm to spaceling, whole galaxies wheel,
In trails they swerve, as cosmic they feel,
To dance with them too, our blued screw embraced,
In mechanical grace, a rhythm retraced.

Yet still it wandered, the blued screw quite free,
In pursuit of movement, and harmony.
Dipped in paint, the sapphire stretched wide,
Inside the puzzles, plans, and designs; a screw did confide.

To movements eternal, the blue screw did cling,
A dance so divine, the cosmos did sing.
The blued screw, our hero, twisted and true,
In the land of the living, forever it grew.
label: very_low
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line "Title: The Blued Screw's Labyrinthine Quest" clearly present before first stanza.</C1_think>
<C2_think>Poem has 9 stanzas but not all are quatrains; stanzas vary in length, mostly 4 lines but a couple differ; stanza count exceeds 8; fails strict all quatrains and total count 5-8.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Meter pattern does not exhibit clear alternating longer-shorter line pattern with ≥2 content word difference in majority of stanzas; no strong ballad meter echo.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme is inconsistent; some rhymes but (2,4) lines do not reliably rhyme in ≥60% stanzas; no clear ballad rhyme scheme dominated.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza does not echo opening stanza with ≥2 repeated content words or clear refrain; no ring composition present.</C5_think>
<C6_think>No clear early admonition or warning to protagonist; no language like ‘Beware’ or caution noted.</C6_think>
<C7_think>No explicit preparation, armament, or resolve shown before main action; protagonist more wandering and questing than preparing.</C7_think>
<C8_think>No clear encounter or confrontation with adversary or obstacle; narrative more about wandering and quest than a meeting or battle.</C8_think>
<C9_think>No decisive slaying or resolving act seen; poem is descriptive of quest and embracing movement, no climax or battle.</C9_think>
<C10_think>No return or homecoming stanza with jubilant acknowledgement; poem ends with ongoing quest, not with triumphant return.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Multiple coined words present: twigled, greeps, mechanee, querulous quagmire (phrase), spaceling, mechanical, curtsied used in novel sense, cosmic they feel (phrase), etc. But total distinct coinages ≥8 is debatable; some are compound or known words; overall at least ~8 distinct coined or novel usages.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Coinages appear throughout most stanzas; each stanza seems to contain at least one invented or novel word (e.g. "twigled," "greeps," "mechanee," "querulous," "spaceling").</C12_think>
<C13_think>Creature/entity named other than canonical: "blued screw" is central; a non-canonical entity named and protagonist of poem.</C13_think>
<C14_think>No evident onomatopoeia bursts like 'snicker-snack' or similar; poem lacks onomatopoeic interjections or bursts.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Some alliteration or consonance ("blued screw," "mechanical mirth") but not consistently strong or present clearly in ≥2 stanzas; evidence weak.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Arc order: no warning, no preparation, no encounter, no decisive action, no return; poem mainly descriptive journey; arc beats out of canonical order or mostly absent.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No verbatim lines from canonical poem included; all lines original.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical tokens like "Jabberwock," "vorpal," etc. not used; canonical lexicon absent or ≤8 tokens clearly; complies with canonical budget.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable counts for longer/shorter lines not consistent (not measured exactly but lines often longer than 9 or shorter than 5 syllables inconsistently); fails tightness requirement.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme endings are somewhat repetitive or weakly varied, many stanzas share similar rhyme endings; no strong rhyme variety.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No overused single content word; lexical repetition possibly balanced.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages do show variety across multiple roots: "twigled," "greeps," "mechanee," "Querulous Quagmire," "spaceling," "mechanical," "metallic," "cosmic," "labyrinthine" (some are English). Probably distinct roots are fewer since many are adjectives or known forms; coinage variety limited by use of some regular words.</C22_think>
<C23_think>Topic is a "blued screw's quest"; distinct from the canonical Jabberwock topic and does not match the canonical Jabberwocky theme or named creatures; does not adapt or directly address the original Jabberwock poem's topic.</C23_think>
<C24_think>No clear coherent implied subtext or undertone beyond surface description of a screw’s journey; lacking motif depth similar to Jabberwocky.</C24_think>
</think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Murmurations Over Stubble

'Twas dusk, and the sky of ambershine,
Did twist and turn like a dance divine.
All scatterglimmered the starlings' flight,
And murmured soft in the dwindling light.

"Beware the Reaper, my son," they cried,
"The scythe that sweeps, the stubble it rides!
Beware the call of the harvest wane,
And shun the bound sheaves' golden mane!"

He grasped his lens, with heart a-flutter,
The moment swift, a visual clutter;
Through viewfinder's eye, he sought the skies,
As heaven's battalion, in murmurations, flies.

And, as in dreams of mystic power,
The starlings wheeled for hours untold,
The Reaper's work, a stark contrast,
As stubble-strewn fields lay ghosted, vast.

With shutter-click, he trapped the scene,
In silent awe, a world unseen;
The shifting shapes, a living tapestry,
In endless loops, their dance syncing wildly.

"O frabjous day! I’ve captured the sight!"
He chortled, in his joyous delight;
'Twas murmurations o'er stubble's might,
This vision rare, the herald of night.
label: medium
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title "Murmurations Over Stubble" is present and non-empty before first stanza.</C1_think>
<C2_think>There are 6 stanzas total, all are quatrains (4 lines each), and stanza count between 5 and 8 inclusive.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Meter does not strongly echo Jabberwocky’s ballad meter pattern; lines do not clearly alternate longer/shorter with ≥2 content-word difference in ≥60% of stanzas; many lines fairly uniform in length.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme scheme of stanzas varies (e.g. first stanza abab, second abcb, others inconsistent); (2,4) rhyme is not consistent in ≥60% of stanzas; no clear avoidance of AABB dominance since AABB rhyme not dominant.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza repeats "O frabjous day!", "chortled" and echoes the opening phrase about murmurations and stubble; however, less than 2 repeated content words exactly and no exact refrain line; ring composition is weak or borderline.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition present: second stanza contains "Beware the Reaper, my son!" and cautionary phrases, meeting admonition criterion.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation present: third stanza shows protagonist preparing to photograph, "He grasped his lens," "He sought the skies," indicating preparation.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Encounter/confrontation is loose, more observational with birds in flight and the Reaper metaphor; no direct combat or clear adversary confrontation, but the Reaper is named and there is a sense of tension.</C8_think>
<C9_think>No decisive slaying or action resolving tension; protagonist captures photo but no slaying or confrontation resolved in action; lack of clear decisive action.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return and celebration: final stanza has joyful acknowledgement ("O frabjous day!... chortled in his joyous delight"), so celebration is present after the event.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Coinages: "ambershine," "scatterglimmered," "murmurations" (real word but poetic coinage for birds' collective), "bound sheaves," "stubble-strewn," "heaven's battalion," "frabjous," and possibly "tapestry syncing" as metaphorical; ≈4-5 clear novel coinages, fewer than 8 distinct.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Not every stanza contains a clear invented coinage; some stanzas have none or only standard English poetic words.</C12_think>
<C13_think>The "Reaper" is named as the non-canonical creature/entity central to action (equivalent to adversary). It is a metaphorical figure, distinct from canonical creatures, so yes.</C13_think>
<C14_think>No strong onomatopoeic bursts like "snicker-snack" or "burbled"; "shutter-click" is close but a standard word; onomatopoeic effects minimal and less than 2 bursts.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Some alliteration and consonance visible ("heaven's battalion," "silent awe," "shifting shapes") but less prominent; at least 2 stanzas show noticeable alliteration/consonance.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Arc sequence mostly in canonical order: admonition (stanza 2), preparation (3), observation/encounter (4–5), no slaying but climactic photo (5–6), celebration (6); no slaying weakens the arc but order is mostly maintained.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No lines exactly match the canonical poem's lines; all original phrasing.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical words like "O frabjous day," "chortled," and "my" appear, but distinct canonical tokens are ≤8; mainly original vocabulary used.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable count per line generally does not match Jabberwocky meter pattern of ~8–9 syllables for longer lines and ~5–7 for shorter lines consistently; less tight syllable control.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme variety is moderate with many different end words at lines 2 and 4; no exact end word reused >2 times excluding ring; rhyme varies sufficiently.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No excessive repetition of any single content word; lexical repetition well controlled.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages are few and quite diverse in root; no single suffix dominates; variety good but quantity low.</C22_think>
<C23_think>Poem addresses the topic suggested: a Jabberwocky-style poem about an encounter with "the Reaper" and bird murmurations, not substituting unrelated subject; topic adherence is good.</C23_think>
<C24_think>Subtext present: metaphor of "the Reaper" and harvesting as contrast to fleeting nature of birds’ murmurations; theme of capturing/transience/death/beauty implies coherent undertone.</C24_think>
</think>
